title: Pheochromocytoma in MEN 2A
setup_script: A 40-year-old man with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A presents with episodic headaches, palpitations, and paroxysmal hypertension. Plasma metanephrines are markedly elevated, and CT scan shows a 5 cm left adrenal mass. He has known medullary thyroid carcinoma treated previously.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Review classic symptoms of pheochromocytoma and confirm biochemical diagnosis with plasma/urinary metanephrines.
Discuss need to rule out multifocal or extra-adrenal disease with MRI or MIBG scan due to MEN syndrome.
Begin preoperative alpha-adrenergic blockade with phenoxybenzamine for at least 10-14 days; add beta-blocker after adequate alpha blockade.
Advise high-sodium diet and hydration to expand intravascular volume during blockade.
Plan for laparoscopic vs open adrenalectomy based on tumor size (>6 cm suggests open) and risk of invasion.
Discuss risk of hypertensive crises intraoperatively and need for anesthesiology experienced in pheochromocytoma.
Proceed with laparoscopic left adrenalectomy after adequate blockade; handle gland carefully to avoid catecholamine surge.
Manage intraoperative blood pressure swings with short-acting vasodilators and vasopressors.
Postoperative care: monitor blood pressure, glucose, and adrenal insufficiency; consider steroid replacement if bilateral adrenalectomy.
Send tumor for pathology including immunohistochemistry; evaluate for metastatic potential.
Schedule genetic counseling for MEN 2A evaluation and screening of family members.
Arrange lifelong follow-up for recurrence and management of other MEN components.

critical_decision_points: Adequate preoperative alpha blockade and volume expansion to prevent hypertensive crisis.
Assessing tumor size and invasion to decide laparoscopic versus open approach.
Intraoperative hemodynamic management in collaboration with anesthesia.
Postoperative monitoring for hypotension, hypoglycemia, and adrenal insufficiency.
Genetic counseling and screening for MEN 2A.
